Completing the square

The technique known as completing the square can be used to solve quadratic equations although it is applicable in many other circumstances too so it is well worth studying.

Observe that the quadratic \(x^2+c=0\), is more easily solved than \(x^2+bx+c=0\). The method of completing the square involves rewriting the equation so that the variable \(x\) appears only in the square term. That is, we can write \( (x+d)^2+e=0\) for suitable numbers \(d,e\). This form is not just easier to solve, it reveals more information about the graph of \(y=x^2+ax+c\), and will be used to simplify expressions appearing in later material such as in calculus.

Example

  1. Show that \((x+3)^2=x^2+6x+9\).

  2. Hence show that \(x^2+6x\) can be written as \((x+3)^2 - 9\).

Solution

  1. Removing the brackets we find \[(x+3)^2= (x+3)(x+3) = x^2 +3x+3x + 9 = x^2 +6x + 9.\]
  2. By subtracting \(9\) from both sides of the previous equation it follows that \[(x+3)^2-9 = x^2+6x.\]
 

Example

  1. Show that \((x-4)^2= x^2-8x+16\).

  2. Hence show that \(x^2-8x\) can be written as \((x-4)^2-16\).

Solution

  1. Removing the brackets we find \[(x-4)^2= (x-4)(x-4) = x^2-4x-4x+16 = x^2-8x+16.\]
  2. Subtracting \(16\) from both sides we can write \[(x-4)^2-16 = x^2-8x.\]
We shall now generalise the results of the previous two examples. Noting that 

\[(x+k)^2=x^2+2kx+k^2\]

we can write

\[ x^2+2kx = (x+k)^2 - k^2.\]

Note that the constant term in the brackets on the right-hand side is always half the coefficient of \(x\) on the left. This process is called completing the square.

Key Point

Completing the Square

\[\qquad \hbox{The expression}\quad x^2+2kx \quad\hbox{is equivalent to}\quad (x+k)^2 -k^2.\]

Example

Complete the square for the expression \(x^2+16x\).

Solution

Comparing \(x^2+16x\) with the general form \(x^2+2kx\) we see that \(k=8\). Hence

\[x^2+16x = (x+8)^2 - 8^2 = (x+8)^2-64\]

Note that the constant term in the brackets on the right, that is \(8\), is half the coefficient of \(x\) on the left, which is \(16\).

Example

Complete the square for the expression \(5x^2+4x\).

Solution

Consider \(5x^2+4x\). First of all the coefficient \(5\) is removed outside a bracket as follows

\[ 5x^2+4x = 5\left(x^2+{4\over 5}x\right).\]

We can now complete the square for the quadratic expression in the brackets:

\[ x^2+{4\over 5}x = \left(x+{2\over 5}\right)^2 - \left({2\over 5}\right)^2 = \left(x+{2\over 5}\right)^2-{4\over25}.\] 

Finally, multiplying both sides by \(5\) we find

\[ 5x^2 + 4x = 5\left(\left(x+{2\over 5}\right)^2- {4\over 25}\right).\]

Completing the square can be used to solve quadratic equations as shown in the following examples.

Example

Solve the equation \(x^2+6x+2=0\) by completing the square.

Solution

First of all just consider \(x^2+6x\), and note that we can write this as \[x^2+6x = (x+3)^2 - 9.\]

Then the quadratic equation can be written as

\[x^2+6x+2= (x+3)^2-9 + 2  =0\]

that is

\[ (x+3)^2 = 7.\]

Taking the square root of both sides gives

\[x+3 = \pm \sqrt 7\]

so \(x = -3 \pm \sqrt 7\). The two solutions are \(x=-3+\sqrt{7}=-0.3542\) and \(x=-3-\sqrt{7}=-5.6458\), to 4 d.p.

Example

Solve the equation \(x^2-8x+5=0\).

Solution

First consider \(x^2-8x\) which we can write as

\[x^2-8x  = (x-4)^2 -16\]

so that the equation becomes

\[x^2-8x+5 = (x-4)^2-16 + 5 = 0.\]

i.e \[(x-4)^2 = 11 \text{ implies } x-4 = \pm\sqrt{11} \text{ and hence } x= 4 \pm \sqrt{11}.\]

So \(x=7.3166\) or \(x= 0.6834\) (to 4 d.p.).
